title: Q: Choosing schemas
body: When collecting a new set of data what should you do first?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

_items.text: Collect some data, don't worry about schema

title: Is the semantic web the future of the web?
displayTitle: Is the semantic web the future of the web?
body:
In 2001, Sir Tim Berners-Lee put forward a vision for the future of the web; the semantic web. This module explores what the semantic web is, its relation to linked open data, RDF and schemas. 

This module examines:

  • What is the semantic web?
  • Adding intelligence to the web
  • Rules, inference and reasoning
  • The semantic web layer cake
  • Is the semantic web the future of the web?

title: Creating a web of linked open data?
displayTitle: Creating a web of linked open data?
body:
So how do we go from inconsistent, unlinked data to that which is richly connected and truly usable?

This set of eLearning modules explores:

  • How all data could be consistently structured using the Resource Description Framework
  • How data can be linked to other data
  • Why APIs are essential to make the web of linked data work
  • The importance of schemas and standards

The set of modules wraps up and looks at what could be achieved if all these technologies are used together.

title: What's next?
body:
Could we create a web of data that machines can not only read, but understand the meaning of what they are reading, in order to interact with it without human intervention?

In 2001 Sir Tim Berners-Lee put forward a vision for the future of the web; the semantic web.

The last module looks at the semantic web as asks if this could be the future of our data infrastructure?

title: Summary
body:
In 2001, Sir Tim Berners-Lee put forward a vision for the future of the web; the semantic web. Essentially the semantic web is one where content can not only be displayed by machines for humans to read, but understood, interpreted and used by those machines to intelligently make decisions.

For the semantic web to function, machines need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the linked open data 5-star rating. Building further, schemas and vocabularies add meaning and allow the definition of rules that can be used to make complex inferences. 

This is a bold vision of the future and as such it is still unrealised in its entirety. Is the Semantic Web the future of the web? There are certainly parts of it that have already seen wide use but the entire stack is not yet complete.  

Main Menu

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Ready to use linked open data schemas?
displayTitle: Ready to use linked open data schemas?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Ready to take advantage of schemas?
displayTitle: Ready to take advantage of schemas?

title: Are you ready to design a REST API?
displayTitle: Are you ready to design a REST API?

title: Applying an RDF schema to data not in RDF
displayTitle: Applying an RDF schema to data not in RDF
body:
In the first module we looked at how all data structures could be mapped to RDF.

However you can also apply the idea of linked data schemas to data without using RDF.

For example in a tabular data structure the column headings as well as all identifiers could become HTTP IRIs.

Shown here is an example where everything that can potentially be an IRI has been converted to one. Note how we have also added columns to define the type of the resource, in this case the Beetles are all people (foaf:person).

title: Applying schemas to RDF
body:
Applying schemas to data in RDF is likely to make some triples long and hard to read. As a solution to this many data formats allow for the use of PREFIXs. A prefix is simply a substitute for the beginning of the URI so we don’t have to keep typing/reading it e.g.

PREFIXmyorg:http://mycompany.org/

What follows is an example of all the different ingredients in use. Note that all of the data (bar the mycompant.org website) is genuine. Thus you can easily follow the links to find out more about each thing.

One of the links you can follow is to dbpedia, a data API for wikipedia that exposes RDF data.

There is also use of the owl:sameAs property which connects two IRIs that represent the exact same thing together.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Linking the predicate
body:
In order to define a schema for RDF data, it is necessary to define the constraints of the relationship against the predicate, in this case "hasStatus". "hasStatus" links a "Company" to a potential status "Active", "Inactive" or "Dissolved". 

The schema would therefor be entirely defined against the predicate. To do this the predicate must become an IRI so that it can be used as the subject in a new set of RDF triples that define the constraints of the relationship.

title: Summary
body:
Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide and automated re-use of data. A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. 

The greatest benefit comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers, something that schemas enable. 

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema.

Next Module Main Menu

title: Having a REST with API design
displayTitle: Having a REST with API design
body:
Consistent availability of data is key to enabling reuse. This module looks at how to design and implement an Application Programming Interface (API) for data. More specifically, this module looks at the importance of an API for resources and the relation of this to linked open data. 

In this module we explore:

  • What is an API?
  • What is a REST API?
  • REST APIs and linked open data
  • REST in practice
  • Designing a RESTful API
  • 'Off the shelf' REST APIs

PREFIX foaf: http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/
PREFIX dc: http://purl.org/dc/terms/
PREFIX dbpedia: http://dbpedia.org/ontology/
PREFIX myorg: http://mycompany.org/person/
PREFIX owl: http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#

SubjectPredicateObject
myorg:Johnfoaf:familyNameLennon
myorg:Johnfoaf:givenNameJohn
myorg:Johndbpedia:birthDate1940-10-09
myorg:Johnowl:sameAshttp://dbpedia.org/
resource/John_Lennon
myorg:Johnfoaf:knowshttp://dbpedia.org/
resource/Ringo_Starr
myorg:Ringoowl:sameAshttp://dbpedia.org/
resource/Ringo_Starr

title: Why do schemas matter?
body:
Open data needs to be simple for anyone to use, whether for a new app, in analytics, research or simply to gain a deeper understanding of a subject.

The greatest use comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. For example, an application that tells you where local toilets are should be able to work everywhere, not just in one town.

An important part of making data consistent is to use the same schema to define the structure and blueprint of the data.

_graphic.attribution: Dublin Core Metadata initiative [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [CC0]
The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: The web of linked data
body:
Welcome to this set of modules which look at a possible future for the web of linked data. 

This set of modules has been put together by the Open Data Institute as part of the Open Data Education  (ODEdu) project. 

There are a total of 6 interactive lessons that will take approximately 2 hours to complete. In part these modules have been designed to follow on from the existing open data modules available on the European Open Data portal. 

We hope you find them useful!

title: Documents: A good start
body:
The web contains billions of interesting documents.

These documents are designed to be read by humans.

Their structure allows us to easily read and interpret the information.

We have always had documents. Before the web, sources of knowledge included books, newspapers and magazines.

title: Data infrastructure
body:
Currently, data on the web is either available as a set of file downloads, or via APIs that require expert knowledge to use. In both cases, the data is so variable that it is difficult to interpret. Additionally it is hard to discover connections to other data; there are no links!

A well designed data infrastructure will reduce friction, increase collaboration and deliver efficiency.

We are yet to build a globally connected data infrastructure.

title: Linked open data and RDF
body:
In the 5-stars of linked open data, the fourth star states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web based so that people can point at your stuff". In this module we look at how the Resource Description Framework (RDF) also recommends the use of web based identifiers and the caveats of doing so.

This module is structured as follows:

  • The connection between linked open data and RDF
  • What are 4-star identifiers?
  • Designing web-based identifiers
  • Implementing services using RDF and linked open data

Transaction data:

SubjectPredicate / KeyObject / Value
#Transaction1Shop#Tesco
#Transaction1MethodIn person
#Transaction1Product#Banana
#Transaction1Cost (GBP £)0.20

Linking the two:

SubjectPredicate / KeyObject / Value
#JohnmadeTransaction#Transaction1

title: How does your data look?
body: Which structure did/would you use to collect your data together from above. Select from the options below and then click submit to find out if you match our thinking (This is not an assessed question).

_items.text: Data about the last thing you bought

_feedback.correct:
Well done!

Data about yourself, looks tabular until you get to the last two questions which could have multiple answers so is more likely hierarchical. 

Data about what you bought is tabular.

Data about projects at work is most likely a network dataset as many people probably work on multiple projects that could share outputs and common characteristics.

_incorrect.final:
It's difficult sometimes to tell...

Data about yourself, looks tabular until you get to the last two questions which could have multiple answers so is more likely hierarchical. 

Data about what you bought is tabular.

Data about projects at work is most likely a network dataset as many people probably work on multiple projects that could share outputs and common characteristics.

title: Exploring the web of data with Pivot
displayTitle: Exploring the web of data with Pivot

title: 'Off the shelf' REST APIs
body:
There are many products and solutions available that offer in-built API and/or REST functionality on top of data repositories or databases.  However the in-built support might not match your own design. 

One of the most popular products for managing web presences is WordPress which has its own REST API. The design of the resource identifiers IRIs does not follow the design pattern outlined in this module however it is possible to extend the WordPress REST API to add your own endpoints and formats.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Adding intelligence to the web
body:
For the semantic web to function, computers need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the 5-stars of linked open data, however these are not sufficient on their own to give the web meaning.

Frameworks like RDF, Schemas and vocabularies are all key ingredients, but for machines to make decisions we must also define rules and implement other techniques from the domain of Artificial Intelligence (AI).

title: Schemas in RDF
body:
A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. A schema will define what the column, titles or keys mean and any constraints on values.

Remember in RDF data in represented as a triple, for example:

SubjectPredicateObject
http://companies.org
/id/0820202		hasStatusActive

In RDF, the predicate indicates the relationship between subject and object, similar to column titles in tabular data. Thus a schema can logically be applied to predicate. 

In the previous module we discovered that a schema is defined in a separate file to the data, meaning in the linkage between data and schema is very lose. RDF solves this problem also, and once again the key is all in the humble link.

title: Q: What is the Semantic Web?
instruction: Pick your answer and then click 'submit'

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The Semantic Web is not a separate Web but an extension of the current one, in which information is given well-defined meaning, better enabling computers and people to work in cooperation.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Semantic Web is not a separate Web but an extension of the current one, in which information is given well-defined meaning, better enabling computers and people to work in cooperation.

_items.text: A web that machines can understand

title: What is the semantic web?
body:
"The Semantic Web is not a separate Web but an extension of the current one, in which information is given well-defined meaning, better enabling computers and people to work in cooperation."

The Semantc Web - Berners-Lee, Hendler & Lassila (2001)

Essentially the semantic web is one where content can not only be displayed by machines for humans to read, but understood, interpreted and used by those machines and agents to intelligently make decisions. Adding structure and meaning to content would "unleash a revolution of new possibilities". Literally a web with meaning, for machines.

title: Q: Why is RDF useful?
body: Why is the Resource Description Framework (RDF) useful?

_items.text: Its simple structure provides data interoperabilty
It's the ideal data format for all data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

RDF is a framework that represents data as a simple triple for better data interoperability and exchange between systems. Because the framework is generic, it is possible to translate from and back to other formats when processing data or using data in applications. But that also means that  while RDF might be interoperable, it might not be immediately usable.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

RDF is a framework that represents data as a simple triple for better data interoperability and exchange between systems. Because the framework is generic, it is possible to translate from and back to other formats when processing data or using data in applications. But that also means that  while RDF might be interoperable, it might not be immediately usable.

title: Q: What does the predicate represent?
body: In an RDF triple, what does the predicate provide?

_items.text: The relationship between subject and object
A simple piece of extra data
Describes how the subject is part of the object

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A predicate describes the relationship between subject and object. In grammar a predicate is the part of a sentence or clause containing a verb and stating something about the subject (e.g. e.g. went home in John went home).

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A predicate describes the relationship between subject and object. In grammar a predicate is the part of a sentence or clause containing a verb and stating something about the subject (e.g. e.g. went home in John went home).

title: Choosing and designing schemas
body:
Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide, automated re-use of data. This module looks at the role of and importance of schemas in assisting reusability and quality of data.

In this module we explore:

  • What is a schema?
  • Why do schemas matter?
  • Schemas in practice
  • Choosing or designing schemas

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Q: Choosing schemas
body: When collecting a new set of data what should you do first?

_items.text: Research and build upon existing schemas
Collect some data, don't worry about schema

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers.

title: Summary
body:
In RDF, a schema can be applied by making predicates a IRI that references a schema. This way users can click on the predicate to look up the schema and machines can use the schema to verify the data. 

There are many schemas already in existence and schema.org has a large community of active contributors. 

This module has also explored how linked open data can be implemented in structures other than RDF, however this doesn't mean it is always a good idea.

RDF proposes a single simple structure for all data reducing the need for complex translations and mappings to take place prior to data being usable by different systems.

The big question is... why aren't we all using RDF already and is this really the future of the web of data?

Next Module Main Menu

title: REST resource identifier template:
body: {scheme} :// {authority} / {path} / {identifier}  [ # {fragment} ] OR [ ? {query} ]

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: REST APIs and linked open data
displayTitle: REST APIs and linked open data
body:
The module RDF and linked open data outlined how web identifiers (IRI) are important to allow people to click on (or "resolve") identifiers to find out what they are. This module also outlined how resolving the IRI should provide both humans and machines an appropriate representation of the resource.

This is best done through the implementation of a REST API for your resources. REST APIs can return responses in the form of JSON, XML or even CSV it means that A REST API can accommodate both the needs of humans and machines.

title: Identifier design template (explained below)
body:
{scheme} :// {authority} / {path} / {identifier}  # {fragment}

e.g.
http :// beta.companieshouse.gov.uk / company / 08030289

title: Q: Why do schemas matter?
body: What key benefit do schemas provide?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Schemas help ensure that the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. Essentially they are talking the same language.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Schemas help ensure that the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. Essentially they are talking the same language.

title: Q: Key features of a schema
body: Which of the following should a schema define?
instruction: Pick you answer and then click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A schema defines column/key titles in the data as well as value types and constraints such as ranges for values.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A schema defines column/key titles in the data as well as value types and constraints such as ranges for values.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]
The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Connections
body:
The above shows a simple example of where many different structures may be required to represent different data. Having many structures means that both humans and machines alike need to understand the structures and how they relate to each other.

The Resource Description Framework (RDF) provides a potential solution, however it requires us to think differently about how we structure data where everything is in threes.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Implementing services using RDF and linked open data
displayTitle: Implementing services using RDF and linked open data
body:
Once you have designed the identifiers for your resources these can be used as subject and object parts of data representations that conform to the Resource Description Framework. Providing human and machine readable representations and formats gives flexibility in both discovery and use.  

Think of using RDF and identifiers as the same as creating human readable Web pages; the identifier is the address, and the RDF is the known structure for the data. Web pages help humans, RDF can help machines.

Web pages are the equivalent of documents. Humans like editing documents in software applications like Microsoft Word or Google Docs, this means that content needs to be available in these formats to allow editing. The same is true for data. For RDF to become usable software applications like Excel need to understand this framework in order to allow both humans and machines to work with it effortlessly.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

title: Summary
body:
This module looked at APIs for data. An Application Programming Interface (API) can be  described as a "promise" by one system to predictably and consistently provide a service to another that allows to the two to interact. 

Specifically this module looked at REST APIs which use the Web's architecture to not only transfer web pages between servers and clients but also allow the same two actors to transact data using both read and write operations. 

Combining good design patterns for web based identifiers (IRIs) with a REST API can enable the web to move from being a web of documents (web pages) to a web of linked open data. A web of linked open data will enable machines to automatically augment our browsing experience and perhaps we will be able to 'browse the web for the first time as if it is actually a web'. 

Watch the video below to find out what might be possible on a web of linked open data. 

Next Module Main Menu

title: Schemas, linked open data and RDF
displayTitle: Schemas, linked open data and RDF
body:
Having introduced all the core concepts of schemas, linked open data and RDF, this module looks at how schemas are applied to RDF and the connection with linked open data. 

This module examines:

  • Schemas in RDF: linking the predicate
  • Choosing or designing a schemas for RDF
  • Applying schemas to RDF
  • Completing the linked open data stack (with or without RDF)

title: Everything in threes
body:
Data about me:

SubjectPredicate / KeyObject / Value
#JohnNameJohn Smith
#JohnAge (Years)22
#JohnHeight (Inches)69
#JohnShoe size (UK)8
#Johnbrother#Ringo
#Johnbrother#Paul

title: Summary
body:
In the 5-stars of linked open data, the 4th star states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web-based so others can point at your stuff".

A good design template for identifiers can also assist with building an intuitive web of linked open data (even if you shouldn't rely on the information you infer from the identifier). Using RDF is not essential to the web of linked open data however the inverse is not true; RDF and linked open data are intrinsically connected through their use of identifiers.

The most important consideration is to use web-based identifiers (URIs/IRIs) to identify resources that people and machines can look up to find out what they are. 

Next Module Main Menu

title: Summary
body:
The Resource Description Framework (RDF) proposes simple framework for representing all types of data, regardless of structure. Using the notion of a triple, RDF maps all data structures into a referenceable network data structure. All current structures can be easily translated into RDF providing that it is clear what the subject, or resource, is to be translated. 

This module has looked at the key aspects of the subject, predicate and object triple. Why not explore how RDF relates to linked data and how the predicate can be used to define standards for working intelligently with data from many providers. 

Next Module Main Menu

title: RDF in real life
body: Follow along practically by collecting some data about yourself. Think carefully about the choice of data structure and try to use the same structure for all data collected in each for the cases. You might end up with different structures per case below.

_items.title: About yourself
_items.body:
Collect together the following data about yourself:

  • Age
  • Gender
  • Height
  • Shoe size
  • Favourite bands
  • Names of brothers and sisters

_items.title: The last thing you bought
_items.body:
Collect together the following data about the last thing you purchased:

  • Shop you bought it from
  • Online or in person?
  • Description of item
  • Cost

_items.title: Projects you work on
_items.body:
Collect together some data about projects you work on (or roles you have) in your workplace.

  • Project names
  • Names of people who work on each project with you
  • Who funds each project
  • Outputs and combined outputs of projects

title: RDF: Three is the magic number
displayTitle: RDF: Three is the magic number
body:
Data exists in a multitude of structures and formats, as explored in module Choosing the right format for open data. This module introduced the three main structures to data; tabular, hierarchical and network. The problem with having these different structures is that each is suited to a different type of data. Given the variety of structures and formats, combining and analysing data in these different structures can be problematic.

The Resource Description Framework (RDF) proposes a solution to this problem. RDF is not a format, it is a common structure able to represent any type of data. The structure can be implemented in any number of formats. A common structure allows any system that can understand RDF to work with all data in this structure, regardless of format. 

  • What is the Resource Description Framework (RDF)?
  • Practical uses for RDF
  • How to translate each data structure into RDF

title: Getting started
body:
Let's get starting by looking at how all data could be structured consistently using the Resource Description Framework. 

Go to module 1

Note that you can return to the main menu at any time, allowing you to navigate freely to other modules on the course. 

Main Menu

title: Q: Match the data to the structure
displayTitle: Match the data to the structure
body:
Select the picture which matches the data from the table below:

SubjectPredicateObject
#PersonA#hasChild#PersonB
#PersonA#hasChild#PersonC
#PersonB#hasSister#personC

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

In this example we have a parent who has two children and one child is the sister of the other. This makes Option D the correct one. Although Option B looks like it could work, we don't know the sex of both children so we cannot say if both children are sisters or one is a brother and one is a sister.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

In this example we have a parent who has two children and one child is the sister of the other. This makes Option D the correct one. Although Option B looks like it could work, we don't know the sex of both children so we cannot say if both children are sisters or one is a brother and one is a sister.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Translating existing data structures to RDF
displayTitle: Translating existing data structures to RDF
body: The guides below look at how data in existing tabular, hierarchical and network structures can be translated into RDF triples of a subject and object related by a predicate.

_items.title: Tabular data
_items.body:
Tabular data should contain one row per subject. Each row will contain values (objects) related to the column headings (keys/predicates).

When translating to triples a subject needs to be added. The subject should be a unique identifier for the thing being described. Many datasets will already have an identifier column and this value could be used. In this example we have used the row numbers as the subject.

Our triple in this example is:

SubjectPredicateObject
#3Last nameMcCartney

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Hierarchical data
_items.body:
In hierarchical data, it should be fairly straight forward to identify the relationships: the predicate is the label that you would put on the line that relates the subject and the object.

In the case here we have:

SubjectPredicateObject
#WilliamhasChild#George
#WilliamhasChild#Charlotte
#KatehasChild#George
#KatehasChild#Charlotte

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Network data
_items.body:
Network data, like hierarchical data, already has subject, objects and connections between them. The difference between network and hierarchical data is that the same relationship can exists in multiple directions (so a subject can also be an object) and you can end up going around in circles.

From the table below see if you can work out which person is which from the drawing shown?

SubjectPredicateObject
#Person1hasFriend#Person2
#Person1hasFriend#Person3
#Person1hasFriend#Person4
#Person2hasFriend#Person1
#Person2hasFriend#Person3
#Person3hasFriend#Person1
#Person3hasFriend#Person2
#Person3hasFriend#Person4
#Person4hasFriend#Person1
#Person4hasFriend#Person3

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Q: Making your data 4-star
body: Which of the following are required to make your resources (things) 4 star compatible?
instruction: Pick the correct 3 and then click 'submit'

_items.text: Make the data available in RDF
Publish a human readable version of your resource
When people click the identifier it should resolve
Create an API for accessing your data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Creating web-based identifiers (http...) enables people to click these identifiers to find out what they represent. To do this each identifier should resolve and provide both a human readable and machine readable version. The formats used should be appropriate for the data (see part 1) and don't have to be of any particular type.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Creating web-based identifiers (http...) enables people to click these identifiers to find out what they represent. To do this each identifier should resolve and provide both a human readable and machine readable version. The formats used should be appropriate for the data (see part 1) and don't have to be of any particular type.

title: Q: Designing identifiers
body: Which of the following are valid 4-star identifiers?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Valid 4-star identifiers look like web addresses, so http://#90 and #08030289 are incorrect. Additionally a valid 4-star identifier should not contain a file extension (e.g. .rdf, .html etc). This leaves the other two valid identifiers.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Valid 4-star identifiers look like web addresses, so http://#90 and #08030289 are incorrect. Additionally a valid 4-star identifier should not contain a file extension (e.g. .rdf, .html etc). This leaves the other two valid identifiers.

title: What are 4-star compatible identifiers?
body: 4-star compatible identifiers should strive to meet a number of objectives. Meeting all of these will make it easy to achieve full 5-star linked open data.

_items.title: 1. Start with http....
_items.body:
Make any identifiers for things (the subjects and objects in RDF) http identifiers.

Using the communication method of the web means that people can easily use a web browser to follow these links to find out more about the things. 

See the next section on how to design good identifiers.

_items.title: 2. Make them resolve
_items.body:
Each http identifier should resolve and offer the user a representation of the thing or the thing itself. This representation could be a document, web page, data or the thing itself (see point 3).

404 (not found) errors and other errors should be avoided where possible to keep the the thing available in the long term.

_items.title: 3. Return the thing (if possible)
_items.body:
If the user does not otherwise specify, then by default the thing being identified should be returned if possible. 

For example; if the identifier is for a digital photograph then the identifier should resolve to the original digital photograph, not a Web page about the photograph (see point 4).

_items.title: 4. Provide a human readable option
_items.body:
If it is not possible to return the original and the user requests a human readable Web page (which is what all Web browsers do) then this is what should be returned to the user. 

Did you know that when a Web browser requests an http page the request looks like the following:

GET http://bbc.co.uk/news HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/html

It is the Accept that tells the provider that the user would like a text based Web page (text/html type).

_items.title: 5. Provide a machine readable option
_items.body:
If the user is a machine, or intended use is for a machine, then a different representation may be more useful, e.g. a CSV (tabular) representation. 

GET http://bbc.co.uk/news HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/csv

If possible the provider should be able to provide a number of different representations of the data, perhaps include one or two that are compatible with the RDF specification.

title: Designing web-based identifiers
body: Follow the guide above to help you design good web-based identifiers. A web-based identifier is made up of five main parts each of which is explored below:

_items.title: {scheme}
_items.body: The scheme in the majority of cases will be http or https (secure). This tells us that the thing being identified can be retrieved via the http protocol, usually with a web-browser.

_items.title: {authority}
_items.body:
The top level domain that is the authority for this web-based identifier.

e.g. companieshouse.gov.uk

It many cases the authority might be the controller for the thing being identified.

Just like web pages, the authority tell the user something about who they are interacting with and helps establish trust.

There might be many paths (separated by "/") that allow the authority to better separate the management and access to identifiers. 

For example there might be a projects path which is publicly accessible and a people path which is restricted. 

Another example path with authority might be:

http://bbc.co.uk/news/politics/
_items.title: {path}
{identifier}
_items.body:
The final part of the path is the identifier for the thing itself.

For example if a company has a company number 08030289 then a web-based identifier for this company might be https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08030289 

Note in this example that the authority has beta in it which suggests that this identifier is unstable and might not be available in the long term.

_items.title: {fragment}
_items.body:
The fragment follows a # and can be used to enable a user to instantly reference a single part or attribute of the thing being identified.

For example given our company 

https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/
08030289#name

could refer just to the name, or for an image

http://images.org/image/123#width. 

It is worth noting that on the web it is the job of the browser to de-reference fragments, the provider should ignore anything after a # in a web identifier. The browser should do the work to return the correct fragment of data after receiving the whole response form the provider.

title: What is an API?
body:
An Application Programming Interface (API) can be described as a "promise" by one system to predictably and consistently provide a service to another that allows to the two to interact. 

One analogous way of thinking of this is to think of spoken languages as an API. Each language has words and grammatical structures that form sentences through which information can be exchanged between people. However not everyone speaks the same language. To solve this problem sometimes you have to learn the new language or use a third party to translate.

The same is true of machines. We would like to ask machines to give us information and we would like them to respond with an an answer that we can understand.  This “conversation” is the (I)nterface with an (A)pplication that we interact with (P)rogramatically.

APIs for specific applications are usually documented and published on the application’s website. Much like a phrasebook documents a language and is made available for people to study. For example eBay publishes its API documentation telling you how you can programmatically ask for information about items or sellers without using the website, and it documents the format of the data you’ll get in response.

Except there are many more applications, and therefore more APIs, than spoken languages so applying some standard design principals to the "conversation" helps everyone understand the API. Much of the conversation on the web is based upon HTTP, the language of the web, but there are still many dialects, just like there are of a single spoken languages. In this module we investigate the REST 'dialect' for API design.

title: Q: Linked open data and RDF
body:
Linking data, i.e. using identifiers that can be followed to external systems, is what earns the fifth star. Fundamentally this is enabled by making data 4-star linkable.

What changes would be required to make the following RDF valid 4-star data and linkable?

SubjectPredicateObject
#09512457hasPostcode#NW12DB

_items.text: Convert just the subject to an IRI
Convert just the object to an IRI
Convert the subject and object to an IRI

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

In this example both the subject and the object are identifiers and thus should be converted to IRIs. The first identifier is a company number and the second identifier is a postcode, both of which are likely to already have existing IRIs (e.g. https://opencorporates.com/companies/gb/09512457 and http://data.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/id/postcodeunit/NW12DB). In this case use of external identifiers should be encouraged, making your data 5-star!

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

In this example both the subject and the object are identifiers and thus should be converted to IRIs. The first identifier is a company number and the second identifier is a postcode, both of which are likely to already have existing IRIs (e.g. https://opencorporates.com/companies/gb/09512457 and http://data.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/id/postcodeunit/NW12DB). In this case use of external identifiers should be encouraged, making your data 5-star!

title: Q: What is an API?
body: Which of the follow best describes what an Application Programming Interface (API) is?
instruction: Pick you answer and then click 'submit'

_items.text: A "promise" by one system to predictably and consistently provide a service to another

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

An Application Programming Interface (API) can be  described as a "promise" by one system to predictably  and consistently provide a service to another that allows to the two to interact.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

An Application Programming Interface (API) can be  described as a "promise" by one system to predictably  and consistently provide a service to another that allows to the two to interact.

title: Q: REST APIs and linked open data
displayTitle: REST APIs and linked open data
body: Which common feature do REST APIs, linked open data and the Resource Description Framework (RDF) all share?

_items.text: Use of web based identifiers (IRIs) to identify resources
The requirement to expose data in the JSON format

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

All of these different specifications agree that using Internationalised Resource Identifiers (IRIs) to identify resources, or things, with web addresses provides an easy and widely supported way to look things up on the web.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

All of these different specifications agree that using Internationalised Resource Identifiers (IRIs) to identify resources, or things, with web addresses provides an easy and widely supported way to look things up on the web.

title: Q: REST in practice
body:
Match the request below to the correct description of what the request represents. 

GET /companies/gb?City=London HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
ACCEPT: text/csv

_items.text: Load a webpage showing companies in London
Retrieve a list of companies in London in the CSV format
Retrieve a single company record in CSV format

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

This request is directed at the /companies/gb endpoint in open corporates (the host). The request also contains a query that asks for records where City=London, filtering the list. The last part of the request asks for the list in CSV format for ease of use on a machine. 

Note: This is not a supported request, but you can find requests that are in the Open Corporates API documentation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This request is directed at the /companies/gb endpoint in open corporates (the host). The request also contains a query that asks for records where City=London, filtering the list. The last part of the request asks for the list in CSV format for ease of use on a machine. 

Note: This is not a supported request, but you can find requests that are in the Open Corporates API documentation.

title: What is a REST API?
body: REpresentational State Transfer (REST) is a way of communicating with machines, via an  API, that was designed specifically for the web. It has a specific set of guidelines and rules that determines if an API is a RESTful API.

_items.title: Uses web identifiers to address resources
_items.body:
In a REST API all interaction is done directly with web-based resources, these resources are specified with web based identifiers (URI/IRIs).

A resource might be “an ebay seller”, or “a photograph”.

Like in linked open data, the IRIs represent the resource itself, not a particular format or representation of the resource (e.g. html).

_items.title: Takes advantage of the web architecture
_items.body:
The web is built using a client-server architecture; to browse the web you do not need to be at the terminal of the computer that holds the files you need.

The web is also stateless, meaning that the server will not maintain information or status of a client between requests. This is the main characteristic which helps the web scale.  

The same must be true of a RESTful API, providing the same benefits of decentralised access and scalability.

_items.title: Uses the HTTP protocol as the language
_items.body:
The main language of a REST API is HTTP. The HTTP specification outlines a series of request methods to indicate the desired action to be performed for a given resource. These request methods are referred as HTTP “verbs” that define how clients can interact with a server and the resources it holds. These verbs allow the client to retrieve (GET), update (POST), overwrite (PUT) and delete (DELETE) resources. 

A REST API that supports all these features is also known as a CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) API.

title: REST in practice
body:
This section introduces the practical use of a RESTful API using the core HTTP verbs. In all cases the interaction is going to be performed with the IRI that represents The Open Data Institute (ODI) as listed in Open Corporates: 

https://opencorporates.com/companies/gb/08030289

_items.title: Retrieve (GET)
_items.body:
The simplest operation we can perform is a retrieve. In the HTTP specification this is referred to as a GET operation since it uses the GET HTTP verb.

The following is what actually happens under the hood when your web browser requests the resource identified by the ODI URI in Open Corporates.

GET /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
ACCEPT: text/html

This GET message requests a specific resource (using the HTTP/1.1 protocol) from opencorproates.com. Here the user (a web browser) is also specifying they would like (ACCEPT) a text/html human readable version.

For a machine to get a machine-readable version the request changes very slightly:

GET /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
ACCEPT: application/json

The request is asking for a different representation that is supported by the Open Corporates API specification. Currently the JSON format (application/json) is the most commonly encountered format of response with REST APIs.

_items.title: Create or Overwrite (PUT)
_items.body:
PUT /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
CONTENT-TYPE: application/json

The PUT HTTP is used to either create or completely overwrite a resource at a given IRI. In this case, because we are asking the server to create a resource the client should provide a representation of the resource to the server and specify which representation with a CONTENT-TYPE header. 

It is important to note that in this PUT request the client has specified the whole of the IRI in the request and the server cannot modify it. The server should simply respond with a status code indicating whether the create was successful or not.

PUT replaces the resource at the known IRI if it already exists, so sending the same request twice has no effect. In other words, calls to PUT are what is called ‘idempotent’.

_items.title: Create or Update (POST)
_items.body:
POST /companies/gb/ HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
CONTENT-TYPE: application/json

If the IRI is created by the server then a POST should be used to add something to a collection. 

The request above is asking "create me a new company using the JSON data I'm sending you in this message".

This would result in a new company entry in the open corporates databases. In response the server should then respond with the IRI of the new company resource (or appropriate error message). 

A POST request is not necessarily idempotent. Two identical requests to the same endpoint could very well result in two identical companies with different IRIs.

_items.title: Other operations
_items.body:
There are a series of other useful HTTP verbs that can be used directly on an IRI including:

HEAD: Identical to GET but the data or documents is not returned by the server, just a description of the requested content (known as headers). These headers include metadata such as last-modified which is used for checking if a resource has changed since the user (browser) last requested it. 

DELETE: Delete the resource and all representations. Any further GET/HEAD requests should result in a HTTP status code "410 Gone" response from the server.

OPTIONS: See which HTTP verbs the server supports on a given IRI.

PATCH: Partially update a resource (not widely supported).

title: Schemas in practice
body:
Schema's can be applied regardless of data structure. 

Explore each of the following to find out how.

_items.title: Tabular data schemas
_items.body:
A schema for tabular data will define the column titles (keys) and valid values that can be contained in each column. 

In desktop applications like excel, column titles can be simply created through typing them in the top row of the sheet. The problem with this is they can be easily changed. Many workbooks use data entry forms to prevent the data structure being changed so easily. 

The data validation function in excel can enforce rules on what valid values can exist and even allow the selection from a pre-defined list of values. 

A slight issue with excel is that data portability is not very easy as the schema and validations rules cannot be exported from an Excel file and applied to another dataset. 

FirstName

LastName

Instrument

DateOfBirth

John

LennonVocal1940-10-09

Paul

McCartneyBass Guitar1942-06-18

George

HarrisonGuitar1943-02-25

Ringo

StarrDrums1940-07-07

_items.title: XML Schema Definition (XSD)
_items.body:
It is possible to import a schema into Excel, however these have to be defined in the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) format and conform to the XML Schema Definition (XSD) standard.

XML is a hierarchical file format and thus can be challenging to implement for tabular data. 

The example below shows part of the schema definition for the tabular data shown previously. The full schema can be downloaded here. 

Such schema can be used by machines to automatically validate the structure and contents of a datasets. One key advantage of XSD schemas is that they can used with a wide variety tabular and hierarchical data formats.

Why not try using the schema from above with an online validation tool against the same data in XML?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: JSON Schema
_items.body:
XSD provides a good specification for schema definitions, however XML is challenging to create and use. The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) schema format provides a much simpler alternative.

Additionally unlike XML, JSON is also natively supported by the Javascript programme language which is used widely on the web. This means it is much more effluent to use and does not require complex parsers to translate from one format to another. 

Shown here is the JSON schema for our tabular data file. Try if for yourself by downloading the tabular data (in CSV) and schema (in JSON) and then using csvlint (a tabular data validator) to validate that the data conforms to the schema. 

Note that XSD is still a far more developed schema definition than JSON schema. As can be seen from this example JSON schema does not have a way to validate the range of inputs currently.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Choosing and designing schemas
body: The choice (or design) of schema for a dataset is a major factor in how useful your data will be to others, both humans and machines. Using existing and widely adopted schemas both helps others use your data and ensures that you can use data from others.

_items.title: Using an existing schema
_items.body:
The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers. 

Many data controllers already have a well defined set of supported schema and using them could be as simple as simply renaming some column titles.

In other cases it might be necessary to change the values in data to conform to the schema, e.g. ensuring that units of measurement and date formats match the requirement of the schema.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body:
No common schema for the dataset you are publishing?

Before creating a new one, why not find out whether there is already some consensus among an existing community of users somewhere (for this, use your favourite search engine).

You might need to contribute a new schema but there may be an opportunity to get the community to help.

title: What is a schema?
body:
A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. 

The schema will define a number of key things:

_items.title: Column/Key titles in the data
_items.body:
Defining a consistent set of column titles (or keys) for a data set is essential to ensure that datasets of the same type can be merged and analysed easily. 

If column titles change (for example be abbreviated to save time) this causes a lot of problems as machines may not know that the columns refer to the same thing and should be aligned. 

Adding completely new columns causes less of a problem.

_items.title: Value types
_items.body:
With the column title/keys defined it is important to define the valid data type for the values, e.g. number, text, date, co-ordinate etc. 

This will help with a simple datatype validation and help catch simple errors such as a value being entered in the wrong column.

_items.title: Value constraints
_items.body:
With the value data type defined we can add constraints about the data value such as: must exist (mandatory), must be unique, must be in a certain unit (e.g. Gallons (UK)) or be within a certain range. 

For example a column might be entitled "Cost (£m)"; thus we can require that any values should be numbers and without commas.

Setting a valid range helps avoid or explain any errors in the data. For example you could define a valid range of 0.001-100 on the "Cost (£m)" column (if it is known that cost cannot exceed £100m).

Range validation stops people accidentally misreading the column title/units and entering 100000000 instead of 100 for £100m.

title: Q: Tabular data and linked open data
displayTitle: Tabular data and linked open data
body: What is the easiest way to turn tabular data into linked open data?

_items.text: Export the data in RDF format
Add IRIs for resources in the data and use web based schemas for column titles
Translate the tabular data into network data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

It is possible to create linked open data in the tabular structure by replacing any identifiers with IRIs and column headings with references (IRIs) to linked open data schemas. In principal you would hide the link to make it easier to read in excel but these would not export into CSV.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

It is possible to create linked open data in the tabular structure by replacing any identifiers with IRIs and column headings with references (IRIs) to linked open data schemas. In principal you would hide the link to make it easier to read in excel but these would not export into CSV.

title: Choosing and designing schemas
body:
The first rule of writing schemas in RDF? Don’t! Find one that already exists that does the job you need. Sites like schema.org contain a broad set of community defined and supported schemas. 

Schema.org is an initiative designed to “create and support a common set of schemas for structured data markup on web pages”. They propose a method for using the schema.org vocabulary in a number of data formats of all structures. This also includes recommendations on how use on website can be recognised by search engines and users to make the web more machine readable (see Semantic Web module).

Some of the most popular RDF schemas are outlined below. If you really need to create a schema then the w3c primer guide can help, but is complex.

_items.title: FOAF
_items.body:
FOAF (Friend Of A Friend) is a schema blueprint for describing people, their activities and their relations to other people and objects. Anyone can use FOAF to describe themselves. FOAF allows groups of people to describe social networks without the need for a centralised database. 

FOAF contains definitions for properties including:

  • name
  • mbox
  • knows
  • homepage

Read more on wikipedia

The Dublin Core Schema is a small set of terms that can be used to describe web resources (video, images, web pages, etc.), as well as physical resources such as books or CDs, and objects like artworks.

Some of the core terms include:

  • Title
  • Creator
  • Description
  • Publisher
  • Source
  • Rights

Read more on wikipedia.
_items.title: Dublin Core

_items.body: Simple Knowledge Organization System (SKOS) is a designed for representation of thesauri, classification schemes, taxonomies, subject-heading systems, or any other type of structured controlled vocabulary.
_items.title: SKOS

body:
http://www.w3.org/2000/
01/rdf-schema#subject

http://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/familyName

http://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/givenName

http://www.w3.org/1999/~02/
22-rdf-syntax-ns#type

http://dbpedia.org/
ontology/birthDate

http://mycompany.org/
people/John

LennonJohn

http://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/Person

1940-10-09

http://mycompany.org/
people/Paul

McCartneyPaulhttp://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/Person		1942-06-18

http://mycompany.org/
people/George

HarrisonGeorgehttp://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/Person		1943-02-25

http://mycompany.org/
people/Ringo

StarrRingohttp://xmlns.com/foaf/
0.1/Person		1940-07-07

title: Completing the linked open data stack (with or without RDF)
displayTitle: Completing the linked open data stack (with or without RDF)
body:
This series of modules have now covered the complete set of theory and principals to deliver the web of linked open data. 

So let's summarise:

_items.body: Tell humans and machines they can use your resources, regardless of data format or type etc.
_items.title: 1. An open licence

_items.body: Release your resources in a human re-usable format so people can instantly use them, regardless of it they are properly structured, machine readable or linked.
_items.title: 2. A human readable format to maximise re-use

_items.body: Release your data in a a properly structured, machine readable and open format.
_items.title: 3. A machine readable version
4. Use web based identifiers for your resources
_items.body:
If you use identifiers or have a schema, why not make it a web based one by adding HTTP IRIs for resources and column headings, even in a format like CSV!

If you create your own HTTP identifiers these need to resolve and offer and human readable (done in step 2) and machine readable (done in step 3) version of each resource that has an identifier.

_items.title: 5. Link to others resources
_items.body: Use others schemas, link to other authorities when referring to resources and make your own resources referenceable.

title: The Semantic Web Layer Cake
body: The Semantic Web Stack (or Layer Cake) is an illustration of the hierarchy of languages, where each layer exploits and uses capabilities of the layers below. It shows how technologies that are standardised for Semantic Web are organised to make the Semantic Web possible. It also demonstrates how the Semantic Web can be built on a base of existing technologies.

_items.body:
The base of stack consists of unicode (internationalised) identifiers or IRIs. These IRIs provide a means to uniquely identify resources on the web. 

IRIs are also a core part of the linked open data 5-star requirement.
_items.title: 1. Unicode identifiers

_items.body:
The next layer proposed a syntax and format for data exchange and representation. In the layer cake this is the eXtensible Markup Language (XML). 

XML is meant to provide a human-readable and machine-readable format for documents. Trying to combine both human and machine readability has received some critisism and preference towards simpler formats, more structured formats such as JSON and YAML.
_items.title: 2. Syntax (XML)

_items.body:
The next layer introduces the standard triple structure (RDF) to represent data, schemas and rules. RDF provides a simple structure that ensures that all machines that understand the triple notion as defined can import and use any data in that structure. 

Of note is the question of why the syntax is lower in the stack than RDF? RDF is a framework that can be represented in many syntax, so picking XML is potentially misleading.
_items.title: 3. Data interchange, schemas and rules etc

_items.body:
Even with all of the knowledge representation, how do you manage the open and closed world models? How do you know if the data can be trusted or is fake?

This layer of the cake is meant to address those problems and involve further theory from Artificial Intelligence (AI) to help accurately model the world. To this day this layer remains the most under-developed.
_items.title: 4. Logic, proof and trust

title: Q: Rules, inference and reasoning
body:
Given the following set of premises, select the correct inference from the options given.

  1. Martha is Female
  2. Shelly is Female
  3. Brenda isMotherOf Shelly
  4. Martha isChildOf Brenda

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The human brain is very good at inferring that Matha and Shelly are sisters, Brenda is the mother of Martha and by reasoning Brenda must be older than her children. For a machine to reason this a set of rules must be defined that humans automatically know. This is one of the biggest challenges with realising the vision of the Semantic Web.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The human brain is very good at inferring that Matha and Shelly are sisters, Brenda is the mother of Martha and by reasoning Brenda must be older than her children. For a machine to reason this a set of rules must be defined that humans automatically know. This is one of the biggest challenges with realising the vision of the Semantic Web.

_items.text: Brenda is the mother of Martha

title: Q: Adding intelligence to the web
body: Which three ingredients are required to help build the semantic web?
instruction: Select three answers and then click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!

For the semantic web to function, computers need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the linked open data 5-star rating. Schemas and vocabularies are critical to add meaning and allow the representation of real world objects in data. Finally, for machines to be able to make decisions, research from the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) needs to contribute sets of inference rules that machines can use to conduct automated reasoning.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

For the semantic web to function, computers need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the linked open data 5-star rating. Schemas and vocabularies are critical to add meaning and allow the representation of real world objects in data. Finally, for machines to be able to make decisions, research from the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) needs to contribute sets of inference rules that machines can use to conduct automated reasoning.

_items.body:
Rules set out a explicit set of principals and conditions that govern conduct. On the semantic web they set out the conditions that define the world as represented in data. 

This is mainly achieved through the use of schemas. Schemas might define rules which state that in order for two resources to be brothers both must be people and both must be male. The hasBrother relationship can only exist between two people where the brother in question must be male. 

These rules help control inferences on the semantic web.
_items.title: Rules

_items.body:
Inferences are steps in reasoning. On the semantic web inference typically takes the form of deduction where logical conclusions are formed from premises such as:

John hasBrother Paul (Known, True)

According to the schema (rules) hasBrother can only exist between two people and the brother has to be male. Given this it is possible to infer:

John is a Person (Inferred, True)
Paul is a Person (Inferred, True)
Paul is Male (Inferred, True)

However care should be take with open world assumptions:

All apples are fruit (Known, True)
All bananas are fruit (Known, True)
All apples are bananas (Inferred, False)
_items.title: Inference

_items.body:
Reasoning is where a number of inferences are put together to establish new facts. 

For example given the following:

Alex-I isBrotherOf Nicholas-I
Nicholas-I isFatherOf Alex-II

We could define a rule which is a compound:

isUncleOf isChainOf isBrotherOf and isFatherOf

Therefor a reasoner could deduce that

Alex-I isUncleOf Alex-II
_items.title: Reasoning

title: The connection between linked open data and RDF
displayTitle: The connection between linked open data and RDF
body:
The 5-stars of linked open data (pictured here) outline steps to publish linked open data. Of particular interest to us here is the fourth star, which states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web-based so people can point at your stuff".

Take for example a company. The unique identifier for a company is usually the registered company number (e.g. 08030289). To find the company from this number, you would have to type it into a search engine and hope that the company is described somewhere together with the company number - somehow near the top of the results. By contrast, you can follow a web-based identifier, a hyperlink, for the same company directly from any Web browser and be sure to find some information on that company, e.g.
https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08030289.

In the triple structure of the RDF, the company number might be the identifier of the subject which is then described in RDF, e.g. 

SubjectPredicateObject
#08030289hasNameOPEN DATA INSTITUTE

Making the subject a web-based identifier is a logical step to allow users to discover more about the company and even the data itself. You can find out more in this module.

title: Introducing RDF
body:
Currently, many data structures have the idea of a key-value pair, e.g. for data about me:

KeyValue
NameJohn Smith
Age (Years)22
Height (inches)69
Shoe size (UK)8

RDF takes the key-value idea an adds the notion that we need a third item, known as the subject. In this case the subject is me, e.g.

SubjectPredicate / KeyObject / Value
#JohnNameJohn Smith
#JohnAge (Years)22
#JohnHeight (inches)69
#JohnShoe size (UK)8

In RDF, the key is referred to as a predicate and the value referred to as the object. Thus the three items are known together in a relationship of "triples" as the subject, predicate and object.

title: Avoiding traps
body: As the use of identifiers on the Web evolves, it is good to learn from the experience of others in what and what not to do.
instruction: Explore the rules below to find out more

_items.title: 1. The lingo
_items.body:
Web-based identifiers are more commonly referred to as Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) which are different from Uniform Resource Locators (URLs). 

A URI is an identifier, however a URL is a subset of a URI that also provides a means to locate the resource being identified.

One problem with URLs and URIs is they don't tend to support Chinese characters, thus the notion of an IRI (Internationalised Resource Identifier) was introduced in place of URI.

_items.title: 2. Don't read too much from a URI/IRI
_items.body:
The only thing you can use an identifier for is to refer to an object. When you are not dereferencing, you should not look at the contents of the URI string to gain other information.

- Tim Berners-Lee

There is a tradeoff between using URIs that accurately describe things and the requirement that the same URI should always return the same resource (in other words it should “resolve”) even if the real world location of the resource has moved.  Humans, and perhaps search engines, might make some assumptions about the resource and its context as described the URL but we should never depend on that meaning.

For example we can deduce from the URI http://www.biguniversity.com/maths/datascience that datascience is part of the maths department.  But one day the subject may be promoted to its own department. The old URI will should now redirect to a new http://www.biguniversity.com/datascience URI, but anyone making assumptions based on the old URI will now be mistaken

_items.title: 3. Don't include file formats in identifiers
_items.body:
The identifier should not include a file format extension (e.g. ".csv",".json", ".html" etc). The format preference should be specified by the requestor. This allows the requestor to access a format (or representation) of the resource most appropriate to the intended usage.

Format negotiation should either use HTTPs provided Content Negotiation mechanism and/or a query parameter. More information on content negotiation and query parameters can be found in the REST/APIs module.

_items.title: 4. Don't use underscores in URI/IRIs
_items.body:
Most systems that display links for people to read will underline these (showing they can be clicked on). When the text is underlined any underscores "_" in them might get obscured. 

In place a hyphen should be used. 

Some pages on wikipedia fall foul of this problem, e.g. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_negotiation

_items.title: 5. Use plurals in paths
_items.body:
When defining the path it is a good idea to use plurals for any nouns (e.g. companies not company). This way if you remove the individual identifier from the end of the URI a user could expect to be able to look up a list of all things at that path. This way the URI still makes sense. 

Of course a user should never absolutely depend on this behaviour, bearing in mind Rule 2 above, but it does make for more intuitively navigable systems.

title: Is the Semantic Web the future of the Web?
displayTitle: Is the Semantic Web the future of the Web?
body:
Since its definition in 2001, the Semantic Web has seen broad use in academia and specific research institutions however has failed to reach its proposed potential. As early as 2006 a number of the original authors revisited the idea pondering why large-scale adoption and benefit had not been realised. Perhaps the lack of adoption is due to complexity and attempt to make a complete model of the world. 

Maybe the Semantic Web will be similar to Microcosm, an early competitor to the web. Like the Semantic Web, Microcosm was more powerful and versatile than the World Wide Web however this strength was also its weakness. Like the Semantic Web, Microcosm never really had practical solutions to all parts of its stack and by the time they were thought about the Web had taken off. 

The whole Semantic Web stack is not yet complete (as of 2018) and while some of the principals like RDF are useful, other parts of the stack, such as XML, have been overtaken with formats such as JSON. It will be interesting to see over the coming decades how the web continues to evolve, perhaps one day we might realise the vision of the Semantic Web, or we might see something else.

title: Exploiting the link
body:
The web revolutionised the spread of knowledge by being a platform open to everyone. The web also provided us a way to navigate between sources of knowledge; the hyperlink.

The hyperlink (or link), allows us to discover more information, simply by clicking to open the next page. This powerful idea at the heart of the web is its most important aspect, but is so simple it goes almost unnoticed. 

So why are we so far behind with data?

title: Q: Schemas in RDF
body: Which part of the RDF triple needs changing to accommodate use of schemas?
instruction: Pick your answer and then click 'submit'

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Just like in tabular data, the schema defines the column title (or key) and any constraints. In the case of RDF the key is the predicate. Making the predicate an IRI allows users to click on the predicate to discover the schema.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Just like in tabular data, the schema defines the column title (or key) and any constraints. In the case of RDF the key is the predicate. Making the predicate an IRI allows users to click on the predicate to discover the schema.

title: Designing a REST API
body: Follow the steps below to design a REST API for your resources and data.

_items.title: Step 1 - Design core identifier structure
_items.body:
Follow the template above to design and document your web-site's structure, i.e. where your resources are going to be, and how they will be organised. This step has several stages:

1. Pick the scheme: http (insecure) or https (secure). 

2. Pick the authority -  You might have already decided that the website base address you have is the right one.

3. Organise your resources into paths - Good resource names are nouns.  Normally paths  correspond to a heirarchy of resource types as a way to organise your data. e.g. /companies /students /news /events /transactions /projects /contracts etc etc

4. Decide on identifier patterns - Are you going to allow clients to create new identifiers (via PUT) or only via POST?

_items.title: Step 2 - Document this structure
_items.body:
The next step is to document your path structure. Usually providers documentation will mirror the design pattern shown above, informing people about the available endpoints. 

e.g. 

List all companies
/companies 

Individual records
/companies/{company-number}
/students/:student-number

Dependant on the documentation standard either "{}" or ":" (see examples above) will be used to denote properties that need to be replaced with the identifier in the URI.

For some examples see the OpenCorporates API and the ODI data API.

_items.title: Step 3 - Decide which HTTP verbs to support
_items.body:
The majority of REST APIs are only for the purposes of retrieving (GET) resources however it might be advantageous to also support the ability to add to the data via the API.

The majority of systems need a way to create resources, but often this is not managed through the REST API for some reason.

Having designed the API, it is now time to decide which representations/formats (e.g. html, son, xml etc) will be supported.

There is no ideal answer here as different applications suit different representations, structures and formats for data. The minimum requirement should be to make available at least one human and one machine readable representation of each resource.
_items.title: Step 4 - Decide on formats/representations
Step 5 - Add support for queries on lists
_items.body:
This optional step enables you to take advantage of query parameters added to list endpoints (IRIs without the identifier on the end) to customise the search for a user. 

For example a GET request to the following location could return all companies with a status "inactive" from open corporates. 

GET /companies/gb?Status=Inactive HTTP/1.1

_items.title: Step 6 - Provide human and machine readable options
_items.body:
As outlined in the previous module, an API should (where possible) accept interactions from both humans and machines.

In addition to providing responses (from GET requests) suitable for humans and machines, a RESTful API may also allow a multitude of different representations (e.g. JSON, CSV, XML) to create and update resources via PUT and POST.
